name: Linear modeling reveals a predominance of cis- over trans-regulatory effects in wild and domesticated barley

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: Barley, like other crops, has experienced a series of genetic changes that have impacted its architecture and growth habit to suit the needs of humans. Domestication also resulted in a concomitant bottleneck that reduced sequence diversity in genes and regulatory regions. Little is known about regulatory changed resulting from domestication in barley. We used RNA-seq to examine allele-specific expression (ASE) in hybrids between wild and domesticated barley. Our results show that most genes have conserved regulation. In contrast to studies of ASE in interspecific hybrids, we find almost a complete absence of trans effects. We also find that cis regulation is largely stable in response to short-term cold stress. Our study has practical implications for crop improvement using wild relatives. Our experimental design allows us to compare the genome-wide expression of two individuals to each other as well as the allele-specific expression of the two alleles of each parent in a single hybrid, allowing for the precise measurement of cis regulatory effects. The accessions used in this study vary by domestication status (4 wild accessions, 2 landraces, and 2 European cultivars). All crosses were made between one of these accessions and the six-rowed American malting cultivar Morex. Morex is also the cultivar which was used to generate the first barley reference genome, which facilitated read-mapping. Exome capture and/or whole-genome shotgun data were used to call informative single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) using standard variant callers. These SNPs allowed us to unambiguously assign reads to either allele. A three-hour cold treatment (4 degrees Celsius) was used to induce a stress response and search for differentially expressed genes in response to cold. There are four replicates for most genotype x generation x treatment combinations, although for some only 2-3 replicates are available. For one combination (Barke hybrid cold), only a single sample is available: after multiple attemps, the other replicates were not successful. The data included here are: 1) the expression matrix (181203_expression_matrix.csv), 2) gene information (181203_gene_info.csv), and 3) information about each sample subjected to RNA-seq (181203_sample_info.csv). There are also 8 subdirectories containing results from the limma analysis. Each directory name has a prefix with the name of the individual accession used for the analysis. Each subdirectory contains 16 csv files: 1) accession..useless info, 2) allele key, 3-5) four different methods (DEseq, edgR, McManus, limma) of regulatory classification, 7) allele-specific read counts (e.g. 181203_Barke_limma_results.csv), 8-9) two methods (DESeq and edgeR) of differential expression results, 10) the linear fit results, 11) gene information, 12) limma results, 13) gene count (not allele specific) matrix (e.g. 181203_Barke_limma_results_matrix.csv), 14), norm factors, 15) the sample key, and 16) voom-transformed count matrix.
keywords: domestication, allele-specific expression, barley, gene regulation

description: Single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) matrices for 1,140 wild barley (Hordeum vulgare spp. spontaneum) ex situ accessions. Genotyping-by-sequencing (GBS) was performed for a total of 1,140 samples, mainly from the German federal ex situ genebank bank hosted at the Leibniz Institute of Plant Genetics and Crop Plant Research (IPK) Gatersleben, but including also samples from the Swiss and Chinese national genebanks (Mascher, 2018: http://dx.doi.org/10.5447/IPK/2018/9; derived from Milner et al. 2018, https://doi.org/10.1038/s41588-018-0266-x). Imputation of missing genotypes was performed with FILLIN (Swarts et al. 2014, 10.3835/plantgenome2014.05.0023). SNPs with (i) less than 95% missing data, (ii) less than 2% heterozygous calls and (iii) a minor allele count >= 10 in a set of 1,140 wild barleys were used as input for imputation. VCF files were compressed with BGZIP. The reference genome sequence assembly of barley cv. Morex (Mascher et al. 2017, https://doi.org/10.1038/nature22043) was used as a reference. In the header of the VCF files, samples are referred to by the EMBL ENA accession ID of their GBS reads. Further information on the identity and provenance of samples is provided in the table '20190304_BRIDGE_GBS_wild_barley_sample_information.txt'.

name: Hordeum spontaneum
Historical phenotypic data from seven decades of seed regeneration in a wheat ex situ collection hosted at the Leibniz Institute of Plant Genetics and Crop Plant Research (IPK)

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: This dataset provides historical phenotypic observations of 12,754 spring and winter wheat accessions (Triticum aestivum L.) gathered during 70 years of seed regeneration on field at the Federal ex situ Genebank of Agricultural and Horticultural Crops hosted by the Leibniz Institute of Plant Genetics and Crop Plant Research (IPK) in Gatersleben (Germany). Characterized by a highly non-orthogonal data structure, the following traits were recorded: (i) flowering time (FT) which corresponds to days after the 1st of January of each year for winter wheat, and days after the sowing date for spring wheat, (ii) plant height (PH) expressed in cm, and (iii) thousand grain weight (TGW) evaluated in g. The dataset also provides information about accession numbers, accession identifiers, sowing date, harvest year and origin country as well as monthly weather records for 63 regeneration years. The dataset and metadata are formatted using the ISA-Tab format (see subfolder /Original_data_ISATab). A previously described quality assessment pipeline has been used to derive outlier corrected data, which serve to compute the Best Linear Unbiased Estimates (BLUEs) allowing for the direct comparison of accessions across regeneration years (see subfolder /Processed_data). Example R-scripts for outlier correction and computation of BLUEs were included (see subfolder /R_scripts).
keywords: Wheat, Triticum aestivum, Genebank, Seed regeneration, Historical phenotypic data, Flowering time, Plant height, Thousand grain weight, Weather data, Outlier correction, Best Linear Unbiased Estimators (BLUEs), Bio-digital resource center, ISA-Tab

name: Triticum vulgare
Initial description of the Aeluropus littoralis genome.

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: The use of wild plant species or their halophytic relatives has been considered in plant breeding programs to improve salt and drought tolerance in crop plants. Aeluropus littoralis serves as halophyte model for identification and isolation of novel stress adaptation genes. A. littoralis was described as perennial monocot grass with an estimated small haploid genome of 349 Mb. A. littoralis is using the C4 mechanism for carbon fixation. A. littoralis grows in damp or arid areas, often salt-impregnated places and waste land in cultivated areas. A. littoralis can survive where the water salinity is periodically high and tolerate high salt concentrations in the soil up to 1100 mM sodium chloride. Therefore A. littoralis serves as valuable genetic resource to understand molecular mechanisms of stress-responses in monocots. The knowledge can potentially be used for improving tolerance to abiotic stresses in economically important crops. Several morphological, anatomical, ecological, and physiological traits of A. littoralis have been investigated so far and also the transfer of stress related genes to other species resulted in enhanced stress resistance. Meanwhile, a number of ESTs (expressed sequence tag), genes and promoters induced by the salt and drought stresses were isolated, sequenced and annotated at a molecular level. Here we describe the genome sequence and structure of A. littoralis analyzed by whole genome sequencing and histological analysis. We hope that the publication of the genomic information will support the functional investigation and application of novel genes improving stress resistance in crop plants. Here the assembled contigs and the predicted genes and their respective aminoacid sequences are presented. The A. littoralis de novo sequence was constructed using CLC assembly cell version 4.3.Gene prediction was done with GeMoMa using gene models of Brachypodium distachyon (Brachypodium_distachyon_v3.0, INSDC Assembly GCA_000005505.4, Feb 2018), Oryza sativa (IRGSP-1.0, INSDC Assembly GCA_001433935.1, Oct 2015) and Sorghum bicolor (Sorghum_bicolor_NCBIv3, INSDC Assembly GCA_000003195.3, Apr 2017).
keywords: Aeluropus littoralis, genome  information, gene prediction, contigs

name: Single-nucleotide polymorphism matrices for 403 barley genotypes (WHEALBI diversity panel)

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: Single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) matrices for a diversity panel of barley (Hordeum vulgare L.) accessions belonging to the WHEALBI panel. Exome sequences that revealed substantial variation in the barley genepool were obtained and validated. Data were successfully derived for 403 genotypes from the WHEALBI research project (EU FP7 no. FP7-613556), comprising formally bred cultivars, landraces and wild barley lines. This source material represents a range of worldwide barley genetic diversity, assembled to quantify variation and explore adaptation, and possible breeding responses (http://www.whealbi.eu/). The reference genome sequence assembly of barley cv. Morex (Mascher et al. 2017, Nature [doi:10.1038/nature22043]) was used as a reference. More than 64 million SNPs were extracted from sequences, which after applying a quality criterion of at least 80 % of genotypes being represented at a SNP locus was reduced to just under 2.1 million SNPs. All seven of barley’s chromosomes (1H to 7H) were well covered, with a range of 262,014 (6H) to 334,501 (2H) polymorphisms and a median distance between SNPs of between 14 and 27 bp, although a few large gaps in coverage remained, especially close to centromeres. Further details can be read in Bustos-Korts et al. 2019, The Plant Journal.
keywords: barley, Hordeum vulgare, genetic diversity, next-generation sequencing, exome capture, single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), plant genetic resources

name: Hordeum spontaneum
Pseudomolecules and annotation of the second version of the reference genome sequence assembly of barley cv. Morex [Morex V2]

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description:
DNA sequence file in FASTA format for chromosomal pseudomolecules of 
barley (Hordeum vulgare) cv. Morex. This is the second release (Morex 
V2) of the Morex genome sequence assembly, improving on the Morex V1 
release by Mascher et al. 2017, Nature [doi:10.1038/nature22043].  
Sequence assembly was performed with the TRITEX pipeline 
(https://tritexassembly.bitbucket.io). Intermediate results (unitig, 
scaffold and super-scaffold sequences) are provided in the folder 
'contig_and_scaffold_sequences'.
The folder 'gene_annotation' holds the structural gene annotation of the 
Morex V2 assembly: gene models in GFF3 format, their functional 
descriptions as well as coding and protein sequences of high- and 
low-confidence genes.
The folder 'repeat annotation' contains GFF files specifying the 
positions of transposable elements and tandem repeats.
A table with the approximate centromere positions is found in the folder
'centromere_positions'.
keywords: barley, Hordeum vulgare, genome sequence asssembly, reference genome sequence, short-read assembly, gene annotation, repetitive elements

name: High-throughput phenotyping reveals strong temporal dynamics of QTL action on plant growth in canola

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: A major challenge of plant biology is to unravel the genetic basis of complex traits. We took advantage of recent technical advances in high-throughput phenotyping in conjunction with genome-wide association studies to elucidate genotype-phenotype relationships at high temporal resolution. A diverse Brassica napus population from a commercial breeding programme was analysed by automated non-invasive phenotyping. Time-resolved data for early growth-related traits, including estimated biovolume, projected leaf area, early plant height, colour uniformity were established and complemented by fresh and dry weight biomass. Genome-wide SNP array data provided the framework for genome-wide association analyses. Using time point data and relative growth rates, multiple robust main effect marker-trait associations for biomass and related traits were detected. Candidate genes involved in meristem development, cell wall modification and transcriptional regulation were detected. Our results demonstrate that early plant growth is a highly complex trait governed by several medium and many small effect loci, most of which act only during narrowly defined phases. These observations highlight the importance of taking the temporal patterns of QTL/allele actions into account and emphasize the need for detailed time-resolved analyses to effectively unravel the complex and stage-specific contributions of genes affecting growth processes that operate at different developmental phases.
keywords: biomass, Brassica, genome-wide association studies (GWAS), growth dynamics, high-throughput phenotyping, vegetative development

name: Interspecific competition among catch crop root biomass distribution and its influence on nitrogen and phosphorus scavenging in soils

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: The potential of a plant species to acquire nutrients depends on its ability to explore the soil by its root system. Co-cultivation of different species is anticipated to lead to vertical root niche differentiation and thus to higher soil nutrient depletion. Using a qPCR-based method we quantified root biomass distribution of four catch crop species in vertical soil profiles in pure vs. mixed stands. Pure stands of mustard (Sinapis alba) and phacelia (Phacelia tanacetifolia) robustly reached 70 cm soil depth, while oat (Avena strigosa) preferably colonized upper soil layers, and clover (Trifolium alexandrinum) developed the shallowest and smallest root system. Analysis of residual nitrate pools in different soil depths and correlation with root biomass showed that, besides rooting depth also root biomass determines soil nitrogen depletion. Soil phosphorus depletion was not affected by the catch crop variant. While occupying the same vertical niches as in pure stands, mustard and phacelia dominated total root biomass of the mix. In contrast, root biomass of clover and oat was severely suppressed in presence of the other species. Below-ground biomass profiling indicated low niche complementarity among the root systems of the examined species. Nonetheless, the mixture mostly overyielded root biomass of the pure stands and thus shows higher potential for efficient soil exploration by roots.
keywords: Root biomass, Shoot biomass, Catch cropping, Soil nitrogen, Soil phosphorus, Sinapis alba, Phacelia tanacetifolia, Avena strigosa, Trifolium alexandrinum

name: WGS assembly, gene prediction and functional annotation of Aegilops speltoides including B chromosomes

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: Data is provided in three directories ‘WGS assembly’, ‘gene prediction’ and ‘functional annotation’. 1) The first directory contains the de novo WGS assembly that was constructed with CLC assembly cell (version 5.0) and is provided in FASTA format. 2) The second directory contains the gene models that were predicted with GeMoMa (DOI: 10.1093/nar/gkw092). For the gene models, genomic position and exon structures are provided in GFF format, while protein sequence and nucleotide sequence of coding sequences are provided in FASTA format. 3) The third directory contains the functional annotation data provided as a tab-separated file, containing information from InterPro GO and descriptions from Triticum aestivum functional annotation (B genome) published by Clavijo et al., 2017 (doi: 10.1101/gr.217117.116).
keywords: Aegilops speltoides, B chromosome, de novo genome assembly, gene prediction, functional annotation

name: GO term enrichment analysis based on 229 candidate genes from the Aegilops speltoides B chromosomes

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: GO term enrichment analysis of 229 candidate genes from the Aegilops speltoides B chromosomes. Data tables are provided in four tab-separated files. 1) The first file ‘GO_term_enrichment_wheat_annot.txt’ contains the functional annotation of candidate genes (GO terms) which is based on sequence homology with genes from Triticum aestivum (BLASTP algorithm).  Ninety-five GO term-annotated genes were used as input for the SEA tool of the AgriGO. 2) The second file ‘GO_term_enrichment_wheat_annot_genes.txt’ contains the functional annotation of genes (GO terms) that is based on sequence homology with genes from Triticum aestivum (BLASTP algorithm). Ninety-five GO term-annotated genes were used as input for the SEA tool of the AgriGO. 3) The third file ‘GO_term_enrichment_interpro_annot.txt’ contains the functional annotation of genes (GO terms) based on the InterPro database. Forty-five GO term-annotated genes were used as input for the SEA tool of the AgriGO. 4) The fourth file ‘GO_term_enrichment_interpro_annot_genes.txt’ provides the functional annotation of genes (GO terms) based on the InterPro database. Forty-five GO term-annotated genes were used as input for the SEA tool of the AgriGO.
keywords: Aegilops speltoides, B chromosome, GO term enrichment, candidate genes

name: Phenotypic assessment of growth and coloration dynamics as well as photosynthetic efficiency parameters in barley HvASL mutants and wildtype plants

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: For this phenotypic dataset Barley HvASL mutants and wildtype plants were grown in the IPK high throughput plant phenotyping facility for small plants. Seedlings of 9 different genotypes (7 mutants and 2 wildtypes) were grown for 15 days in single-plant setups in the automated phytochamber and imaged daily using RGB and static fluorescence imaging. Automated image analysis routines implemented in the IAP software were employed for the extraction of growth-related features and coloration dynamics. In addition three times per week seedlings were subjected to kinetic chlorophyll fluorescence imaging and photosynthetic efficiency and quenching parameters were assessed in the light-adapted state as well as during induction of photosynthesis after transition from dark to light. The ‘data’ folder contains the concrete research data files. The metadata fulfill the MIAPPE 1.1 recommendations. They were formatted as ISA-Tab and stored in the ‘metadata’ folder.
keywords: plant phenotyping, image analysis, Hordeum vulgare, RGB imaging, chlorophyll fluorescence imaging, ISATab, MIAPPE 1.1

name: Hordeum spontaneum
Marker matrix of 9k iSelect SNPs used in genome-wide association scans (GWAS) to study biomass formation in spring barley

publisher.name: Leibniz Institute of Plant Genetics and Crop Plant Research (IPK), Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: The uploaded data set contains the SNP matrix, which was used for genome-wide analysis of biomass under drought stress (Dhanagond et al. 2019, Front. Plant Sci, in press) and under well-watered conditions (Neumann et al. 2017, BMC Plant Biol, doi: 10.1186/s12870-017-1085-4). The SNPs are derived from the 9k iSelect SNP array (Illumina, CA, United States) and were filtered for missing data (5%) and minor allele frequency (MAF<0.05), resulting in 4,866 polymorphic SNPs. The 99 two-rowed barley genotypes originate almost exclusively from the IPK gene bank and underwent single seed descent (97, index HOR and BCC).
keywords: marker

name: Hordeum spontaneum
Integrated peak areas of anthocyanins and other polyphenols measured by LC-UV_MS and LC-MS_MRM in a set of coloured potato tubers (Solanum tuberosum L.)

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: The dataset provides integrated peak areas of anthocyanins and other phenolic compounds in potato tuber measured by LC-MS approaches. The given data belong to the study of Oertel et al. 2017 (https://doi.org/10.1007/s00425-017-2718-4) focusing on the phytochemical characterization of the phenolic composition of a variety of coloured potato tubers, both for peel and ﬂesh tissues. First, liquid chromatography (LC) separation coupled to UV and mass spectrometry (MS) detection of polyphenolic compounds of potato tubers from 57 cultivars was used to assign groups of potato cultivars differing in their anthocyanin proﬁles. Tissues from 19 selected cultivars were then analysed by LC separation coupled to multiple reaction monitoring (MRM) to detect quantitative differences in anthocyanin and polyphenol composition. The “ReadMe.txt” contains a detailed description of the provided data files.
keywords: Potato, Anthocyanin, tuber, Genotypes, LC-MS, Phenylpropanoids

name: Tutorial with three data sets providing assistance and guidance of data processing using Kmasker plants

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: Three data sets providing assistance and guidance of data processing using Kmasker plants. Also, we perform a comparison of Kmasker plants functionality with the KAT tool. This DOI holds input and output data of this analysis. Example_1 uses an Aegilops speltoides dataset and results show that tested repeat sequences have B chromosome origin. Example_2 uses the winter barley specific gene VRN-H2 and results show that it is absent in spring barley cultivar Morex. Example_3 uses the full barley gene set and compares winter and spring barley presence/absence. Related commands and updates of this tutorial are provided on GitHub in the tutorial section of Kmasker plants. For the most recent version of this tutorial please have a look to the project page (https://github.com/tschmutzer/kmasker).
keywords: Kmasker plants, Tutorial and training, Example data set, Comparison

name: Hordeum spontaneum

The high-performance airborne imaging spectrometer HyPlant – From raw images to top-of-canopy reflectance and fluorescence products_ An example dataset from the agricultural research station Campus Klein-Altendorf

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description:
The HyPlant imaging spectrometer is a high-performance airborne instrument consisting of two sensor modules. The DUAL module records hyperspectral data in the spectral range from 400–2500 nm, which are useful to derive biochemical and structural plant properties. In parallel, the FLUO module acquires data in the red and near infrared range (670–780 nm) with a distinctly higher spectral sampling interval and finer spectral resolution. The technical specifications of HyPlant FLUO allow for the retrieval of sun-induced chlorophyll fluorescence (SIF), a small signal emitted by plants, which is directly linked to their photosynthetic efficiency. The combined use of both HyPlant modules opens up new opportunities in plant science.

The presented example dataset was recorded on June 29, 2018 at 12.30 MEST and covers a part of the agricultural research station Campus Klein-Altendorf (CKA), which is affiliated to the Agricultural Faculty of the University of Bonn (Germany). The area is located between the cities of Rheinbach and Meckenheim in the western part of Germany (50°37′N, 6°59′E), 40 km south of Cologne.

A detailed description of the presented dataset can be found in the file 'data_description.txt'. Furthermore, descriptions of the single products for each sensor module are provided in the files 'HyPlant_DUAL_product_description.csv' and 'HyPlant_FLUO_product_description.csv', respectively. The image data itself is stored in ENVI band sequential format with the file extension '*.bsq'.

The charactaristics of the HyPlant sensor system are summarized in the file 'HyPlant_technical_characteristics.csv'.
keywords: HyPlant, hyperspectral, sun-induced chlorophyll fluorescence, SIF, SIF retrieval, airborne imaging spectrometer, Agricultural research station Campus Klein-Altendorf (CKA)

name: Genomic and phylogenetic data for the identification of ancient and recurrent hybridizations in wheat taxa

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: Genomic data from 244 loci for 69 accessions representing the diploid Aegilops and Triticum species, as well as some diploid Hordeum species as outgroup (Dataset_S1). The associated 244 maximum likelihood gene trees in Newick format are rooted with the outgroup and branches with bootstrap values below 10 were collapsed (Dataset_S2). Raw GBS data for 57 accessions representing all diploid species from the genera Aegilops, Triticum, as well as Dasypyrum villosum and Taeniatherum caput-medusae as outgroup species (Dataset_S3).

name: Hordeum spontaneum
Genotyping-by-sequencing  data of two double introgression-line mapping populations developped to map the Hordeum bulbosum A42 powdery mildew locus

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description:
This dataset contains the raw GBS data from the mapping populations dIL_4176 and dIL_5216, developped to map the locus of resistance to powdery mildew from the Hordeum bulbosum A42 accession. 
dIL_4176 is derived from the cross between the introgression line (IL) 200A3/7/M1 (named 'IL 88' in the dataset) from the H. bulbosum donor A17 and the resistant IL '4176/26_33', a BC1F6 from the cross between the barley cultivar Borwina and the H. bulbosum accession A42.

SNP matrix and read alignment from 1420 lines of the barley HEB-25 population for candidate gene rec8.

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: Data is provided in two directories ‘01_alignment’ and ‘02_variants_rec8’. Sequence data was aligned to the barley genome reference of cultivar ‘Morex’ in version 2 published by Monat et al., 2019 (DOI: https://doi.org/10.1186/s13059-019-1899-5). The alignment was constructed using BWA mem published by Li 2013 (DOI: http://arxiv.org/abs/1303.3997). SNP variants were detected with Freebayes published by Garrison and Marth 2012 (DOI: http://arxiv.org/abs/1207.3907). The gene ID of the target candidate gene rec8 is ‘HORVU.MOREX.r2.1HG0075790’.
keywords: HEB-25, Hordeum spontaneum, NAM population, barley

name: Hordeum spontaneum
Image test set for Macrobot software validation

publisher.name: Leibniz Institute of Plant Genetics and Crop Plant Research (IPK), Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description:
This data archive contains a test image set for validating the Macrobot image analysis pipeline (https://github.com/snowformatics/macrobot). The images were acquired using the Macrobot hardware system (https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.03.16.993451). 
The test set consist of one plate with 32 powdery mildew infected wheat leaves (6 days after inoculation, 8 leaves per column).
This is the folder structure:
_gb2_exp40 (experiment name)
____6dai (days after inoculation with the pathogen)
_______20190709_102939_exp40_P02-3 (plate ID)

The plate ID folder contains the following image files:
20190709_102939_exp40_P02-3_001_blue.tif -> blue channel image (470nm)
20190709_102939_exp40_P02-3_002_green.tif -> green channel image (530nm)
20190709_102939_exp40_P02-3_003_red.tif -> red channel image (625nm)
20190709_102939_exp40_P02-3_preview.tif -> RGB image
20190709_102939_exp40_P02-3_004_uvs.tif -> UV image (365nm)
20190709_102939_exp40_P02-3_000_backlight.tif -> background illumination image

For each plate monochrome images in all illumination wavelengths are acquired separately and stored in 16-bit TIFF image files. An RGB image is generated by combining the images of the red, green and the blue LED channels.
keywords: plant-pathogen interactions, plant phenotyping, macrobot, python, computer vision

name: Triticum vulgare
Phenotypic image data of spring barley (Hordeum vulgare L.) RIL population under drought

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: The aim of the study was to use high-throughput imaging in order to assess the variation and dynamics of growth and development during drought in a spring barley population and to investigate associations between traits measured in time and yield-related traits measured after harvesting. Plant material covered recombinant inbred line population derived from a cross between European and Syrian cultivars. After placing the plants on the platform (28th day after sowing), drought stress was applied for two weeks. Top and side cameras were used to capture images daily that covered the visible range of the light spectrum, fluorescence signals, and the near infrared spectrum. The image processing provided 376 traits that were subjected to analysis. After 32 days of image phenotyping, the plants were cultivated in the greenhouse under optimal watering conditions until ripening, when several architecture and yield-related traits were measured.
keywords: automated high-throughput plant phenotyping, barley, drought stress

name: Hordeum spontaneum
Identification of interaction partners of type II peroxiredoxin E (PRXIIE)

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description:
Immobilized recombinant his-tagged PRXIIE from Arabidopsis thaliana was used as bait and A. thaliana leaf protein as prey to identify PRXIIE interaction partners. The interaction partners were identified by LC-MS based comparison of proteins bound to wild type or C146S variant of PRXIIE with those bound to Ni-NTA matrix without PrxIIE as control. 
Raw data files of the protein profiling of the possible interaction partners of PRXIIE: 
1.	The Waters LC/MS raw data files of the protein profiling of Arabidopsis WT and PRXIIE mutant.
2.	Proteins identifications obtained using ProteinLynx Global Server v.2.5.3
3.	The results of label free quantification. The lists include proteins and peptides quantification and statistical data obtained after analysis with Progenesis QI for Proteomics software (Nonlinear Dynamics, Newcastle, UK)
keywords: peroxiredoxin

name: Integrated genomic and phenotypic data for predicting grain yield of hybrids in wheat

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description:
The data contains two files. The first file is the integrated phenotypic data of 988 lines and 4,648 high-quality hybrids. Each row of the data displays the phenotypic record of one line or hybrid. The first three columns denote the female parent, male parent, and name for hybrids and lines. Hybrid names are expressed as a combination of female and male names, using “&&” as a separator. Column 4 to 7 contains the information which lines and hybrid were used in the respected experimental series: 1 and 0 define the presence and absence of the genotype in the experiments, respectively. The experimental series are described in detail in (Zhao et al. 2020). The column “Grain yield” (Mg ha-1) is the across experimental series Best Linear Unbiased Estimation for all the lines and hybrids, grain yield trials are described in detail in (Zhao et al. 2020). The “Type” column indicates whether the genotype is a line or a hybrid. The male line “malemixearly” is a mixture of three lines “apache”, “rocky”, and “kwsferrum”; Male line “malemixlate” is a mixture of three lines “piko”,” henrik”, and “hermann”; Male line “nordsaatmix” is a mixture of two lines “m808” and “m810”; Male line “sur99820sur186” is a mixture of two lines “sur186” and “sur99820”.

The second file is the integrated genomic data of the parental lines. The first column displays the name of the line, and from column 2 onwards we present the 10,522 high quality SNPs from SNP data derived from a public 90,000 SNP array (Wang et al. 2014). Heterozygous genotype calls are coded as 1 and the two homozygous calls are coded as 0 and 2, respectively.
keywords: Winter wheat, Hybrid breeding, Big data, SNP array, Genomic prediction

name: Triticum vulgare
Assembly, annotation and analysis of the barley (Hordeum vulgare L.) pan-genome

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: Annotated chromosome-scale sequence assemblies (a 'pan-genome') of 20 barley genotypes. Sequence assembly was performed using the TRITEX pipeline (https://tritexassembly.bitbucket.io, Monat et al. 2019, [doi: 10.1186/s13059-019-1899-5]). Protein-coding gene models were predicted for all twenty genotypes by gene projection with de novo gene models of three genotypes (including “self-projections”). The folder 'Denovo_gene_annotation' contains de novo gene annotations in GFF3 format and their corresponding CDS and protein sequences in FASTA format for the three genotypes Morex, Barke and HOR 10350. Gene projection results for the twenty genomes are provided in the folder 'Gene_projectionn'. The folder 'Pseudomolecules' includes the twenty genome assemblies in FASTA format. Whole genome alignments of the twenty genotypes detected a large number of presence/absence variants (PAVs). A catalog of PAVs (in BED format) is supplied in the folder 'PAVs'. SNP calling was performed using 300 whole-genome shot-gun (WGS) data as well as genotyping-by-sequencing (GBS) data from Milner et al. 2019, Nature Genetics [doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0266-x] against the Morex genome. These two SNP matrices are provided in the folder 'SNP_matrices'. The folder 'kmer_counts_GWAS_PCA' holds matrices of normalized k-mer counts used for genetic analyses. The folder 'TE_annotation' holds GFF files specifying the positions of transposable elements annotated using two complementary methods. The folder 'Morex_Pacbio_CLR_assembly' contains a long-read assembly of cv. Morex, which was used to validate the short-read assemblies.  Genome annotation and data management were supported by a grant of the German Ministry of Education and Research (FKZ 031A536, 'de.NBI', www.denbi.de).
keywords: genome sequence asssembly, reference genome sequence, short-read assembly, pan-genome, barley, Hordeum vulgare, genetic diversity, structural variation, Triticeae, genome annotation

name: Hordeum spontaneum
Evaluation of wild potato germplasm for tuber starch content and nitrogen utilization efficiency

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: This data set provides original data on the tuber starch content of 28 wild potato accessions, as well as data on the nitrogen use efficiency of selected wild potato genotypes with high tuber starch content. The data are provided in the ISA-Tab format. This research was conducted within the research project „Characterisation of the proteome under nitrogen and water deficiency stress as a basis for breeding of nitrogen-efficient and drought-tolerant starch potato varieties“ (Part B, FNR 22023411) at the Gross Luesewitz Potato Collections (GLKS) of the Leibniz Institute of Plant Genetics and Crop Plant Research (IPK).
keywords: Solanum-species, resource efficiency, in vitro cultivation, genetic resources, stress tolerance

name: Analysis of Wild Tomato Introgression Lines Elucidates the Genetic Basis of Metabolome Variation in a Ripening Tomato Fruit

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description:
LC-MS analysis of the Introgression Lines (ILs; Eshed & Zamir 1995) and Backcrossed Inbred Lines (BILs; Ofner et al. 2016) developped from the wild Peruvian accession of Solanum pennellii in the genetic background of the Solanum lycopersicum cultivar M82. Fruit at the breaker and red ripe stages of ILs and BILs were harvested from the field at the Western Galilee Experimental Station in Akko, Israel. Samples represent methanol extracts analysed using a high-resolution UPLC/qTOF system comprised of a UPLC (Waters Acquity) which was connected online to a photodiode array (PDA) and qTOF detectors. Details on plant material and experimental protocols are provided in attached Methods file. Attached Metadata file provides all details on sample identity, measurement batches and quality controls. The analysis has been performed at the Department of Plant and Environmental Sciences, Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, Israel in the lab of Prof. Asaph Aharoni.
Please visit our GitHub repository (https://github.com/NAMlab/kILBIL) for data processing, annotation and analysis scripts, as well as list of studies using the dataset, and links to further transcriptomic and phenomic data resources for the respective genotypes. 

Eshed, Y. & Zamir, D. An introgression line population of Lycopersicon pennellii in the cultivated tomato enables the identification and fine mapping of yield-associated QTL. Genetics 141, 1147–1162 (1995).
Ofner, I., Lashbrooke, J., Pleban, T., Aharoni, A. & Zamir, D. Solanum pennellii backcross inbred lines (BILs) link small genomic bins with tomato traits. Plant J. 87, 151–160 (2016).
keywords: metabolomics, LC-MS, Solanum lycopersicum, mapping population, fruit, specialized metbaolism, ripening

name: Genomic analysis of wheat cytogenetic stocks for chromosome 1D

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description:
Analysis of genomic deletions in cytogenetic stocks of bread wheat 
(Triticum aestivum) in background of cv. Chinese Spring. Counts of 
mapped reads in genotyping-by-sequencing (GBS) data of 14 genotypes was 
calculated in non-overlapping 1 Mb windows and normalized for library 
size (number of reads). Deletions were detected as contiguous regions 
having low coverage ratios relative to Chinese Spring control (column: 
ratio_sample_CS). One table is provided for each genotype. The IWGSC 
RefSeq V1.0 sequence assembly of Chinese Spring was used for this 
analysis.
keywords: cytogenetic stocks, short-read mapping, genotyping-by-sequencing, Hordeum vulgare, wheat, Triticum aestivum, Triticeae

name: Triticum vulgare
Pseudomolecules and annotation of the third version of the reference genome sequence assembly of barley cv. Morex [Morex V3]

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: DNA sequence file in FASTA format for chromosomal pseudomolecules of barley (Hordeum vulgare) cv. Morex. This is the third release (Morex V3) of the Morex genome sequence assembly. Primary contig assembly from PacBio Hifi reads was done with HiCanu [doi:10.1101/gr.263566.120]. Contigs were scaffolded with Bionano data and arranged into chromosomal pseudomolecules with Hi-C data using the TRITEX pipeline [doi:10.1186/s13059-019-1899-5]. An AGP file specifying the placement of sequence scaffolds in the pseudomolecules is provided. The folder 'gene_annotation' holds the structural gene annotation of the Morex V3 assembly: gene models in GFF3 format, their functional descriptions as well as coding and protein sequences of high- and low-confidence genes. The folder 'repeat annotation' contains GFF files specifying the positions of transposable elements and tandem repeats. A table with the approximate centromere positions is found in the folder 'centromere_positions'. Annotation and data management were supported by the de.NBI grant (www.denbi.de) of the German Federal Ministry of Education and Research (031A536).
keywords: barley, Hordeum vulgare, genome sequence assembly, long read sequencing, reference genome, gene annotation, transposable elements

name: Triticum vulgare
Identification of interaction partners of type II peroxiredoxin E (updated version)

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description:
Immobilized recombinant his-tagged PRXIIE from Arabidopsis thaliana was used as bait and A. thaliana leaf protein as prey to identify PRXIIE interaction partners. The interaction partners were identified by LC-MS based comparison of proteins bound to wild type or C146S variant of PRXIIE with those bound to Ni-NTA matrix without PrxIIE as control. This dataset is an update of a previous version (http://dx.doi.org/10.5447/ipk/2020/15).
Raw data files of the protein profiling of the possible interaction partners of PRXIIE: 
1.	The Waters LC/MS raw data files of the protein profiling of Arabidopsis WT and PRXIIE mutant. 
2.	Proteins and peptides identifications obtained using ProteinLynx v.3.0.2
keywords: peroxiredoxin,  AT3G52960, protein-protein interaction

name: Hordeum spontaneum
Western blot analysis of nuclei extract proteins of wilde type and transgenic Arabidopsis thaliana plants possessing  degradation of specific nuclear proteins via the 26S proteasome pathway

publisher.name: Leibniz Institute of Plant Genetics and Crop Plant Research (IPK), Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: This dataset contains PDF files with the images and diagrams of the created western plots and corresponding text files providing a detailed explanation. Classical genetic approaches to knocking out protein function in plants is challenging. We aimed to overcome this problem by acting downstream of the protein level. Chimeric E3 ligases degrade proteins of interest in mammalian cell lines, Drosophila melanogaster embryos, and transgenic tobacco. We recruited the 26S proteasome pathway to degrade the centromere-specific histone H3 (CENH3) variant in N. tabacum. This was achieved via replacement of the interaction domain of the E3 ligase adaptor protein SPOP with a specific anti-GFP nanobody (VHHGFP4). Therefore the target protein CENH3 of A. thaliana fused to EYFP was subjected to nanobody-guided proteasomal degradation in planta. Our results demonstrate the potential of the modified E3-ligase adapter protein VHHGFP4-SPOP in this respect.
keywords: nanobody, CENH3, Nicotiana tabacum

name: Arabidopsis thaliana
Severe cases of COVID-19 are associated with changes in circulating small RNA abundance.

publisher.name: Leibniz Institute of Plant Genetics and Crop Plant Research (IPK), Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description:
RNA-interference is described as an evolutionary conserved, host defense mechanism against viral infection. Up to now only minor effort was taken to investigate the relevance of this mechanism for clearance of the SARS-CoV-2 RNA virus in infected individuals.

Small circulating RNAs were investigated from serum samples of COVID-19 patients.  Small RNAs were analyzed by high throughput sequencing from five mild cases, five severe cases and two control samples.  

Here, we profile the plasma of patients with mild and severe COVID-19 for the presence of small circulating RNAs during active and convalescene using high throughput sequencing. As result the presence of SARS-CoV-2 derived small RNAs in serum samples of mild and severe COVID-19 cases is described.
keywords: COVID-19, RNAi, SARS-CoV2, circulating-miRNA, small RNA

name: Simulation of chromosome condensation with loop extruders and centromeric nucleosomes

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description:
This dataset contains four movies showing the condensation of a chromosome with centromeric nucleosomes via loop extrusion.
HolocentricChromosome_noEffectCentromeres.mp4 - Condensation of a holocentric chromosome, where the centromeric nucleosomes have no effect on the Loop Extruders. Three visualization modes are present. Chromatin is shown as a 10 nm thick grey fibre, the Loop Extruders are represented by the bound nucleosomes as pairs of yellow beads and the centromeric nucleosomes are shown as beads coloured in red or in a gradient from blue to red, following their chromosome position, as indicated by the subtitles. The simulation presents 1000 LEs and 100 centromeric nucleosomes.
HolocentricChromosome_blockingCentromeres.mp4 - Condensation of a holocentric chromosome, where the centromeric nucleosomes have a blocking effect on the Loop Extruders. Three visualization modes are present. Chromatin is shown as a 10 nm thick grey fibre, the Loop Extruders are represented by the bound nucleosomes as pairs of yellow beads and the centromeric nucleosomes are shown as beads coloured in red or in a gradient from blue to red, following their chromosome position, as indicated by the subtitles. The simulation presents 1000 LEs and 100 centromeric nucleosomes.
HolocentricChromosome_anchoringCentromeres.mp4 - Condensation of a holocentric chromosome, where the centromeric nucleosomes have an anchoring effect on the Loop Extruders. Three visualization modes are present. Chromatin is shown as a 10 nm thick grey fibre, the Loop Extruders are represented by the bound nucleosomes as pairs of yellow beads and the centromeric nucleosomes are shown as beads coloured in red or in a gradient from blue to red, following their chromosome position, as indicated by the subtitles. The simulation presents 1000 LEs and 100 centromeric nucleosomes.
MonocentricChromosome_anchoringCentromeres.mp4 - Condensation of a monocentric chromosome, where the centromeric nucleosomes have an anchoring effect on the Loop Extruders. Three visualization modes are present. Chromatin is shown as a 10 nm thick grey fibre, the Loop Extruders are represented by the bound nucleosomes as pairs of yellow beads and the centromeric nucleosomes are shown as beads coloured in red or in a gradient from blue to red, following their chromosome position, as indicated by the subtitles. The simulation presents 1000 LEs and 20 centromeric nucleosomes.
keywords: polymer simulation, chromosome condensation, loop extrusion, centromere organization

name: Nitrogen and phosphorus accumulation by catch crops grown in pure and mixed stands

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description:
Catch crops are grown to scavenge nutrients for their conservation over a period with unfavorable growth conditions in order to carry them over to a subsequently grown cash crop. Environmental conditions have a strong impact on growth and nutrient capture by individual species; mixtures have been often described to be more durable due to compensatory effects among component species. We hypothesized, that a mixture of mustard, phacelia, oat and clover species is more efficient in capturing nitrogen and phosphorus than their respective pure stands under different growth conditions. During three and two years, respectively, at two experimental locations we grew the four species in pure stands vs. a four-species mixture and accessed their nutrient accumulation in shoots and roots down to 70 cm soil depth. Our results show, that 
i) roots are able to contribute 15-35 % of nitrogen and 25-55 % of phosphorus to total plant nutrient capture, and even more when root:shoot ratios shift towards roots under unfavorable cultivation conditions, 
ii) nitrogen accumulation is strongly depended on the biomass of a species, while phosphorus accumulation depends on concentration in plant tissues as well as on biomass,
iii) the mixture is always among the variants with highest nutrient accumulation, concluding that it is most resilient to environmental changes.
keywords: Root biomass, Shoot biomass, Nitrogen, Phosphorus, Sinapis alba, Avena strigosa, Phacelia tanacetifolia, Trifolium alexandrinum, Soil

name: Tuber yield and starch content of 34 potato genotypes in 14 pot and field trials with optimal and reduced irrigation conducted in Northern Germany 2011 - 2013

publisher.name: Leibniz Institute of Plant Genetics and Crop Plant Research (IPK), Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: In the context of the TROST project, 34 Solanum tuberosum ssp tuberosum cultivars, predominantly optimized for starch production were subjected to 14 independent pot or field trials to quantify the interaction between genotype and water supply (control, drought) on starch content and fresh weight of tubers at harvest. Plants in pot trials were grown from in vitro cuttings in 4liter-pots on peat-based horticultural substrate under controlled climate conditions (Potsdam-Golm) or in a rainout shelter (Groß Lüsewitz) in NE Germany. Field trials were conducted on three sites in Northern Germany in 2011, 2012 and 2013. Drought stress was applied by reducing the amount of irrigation water to a fixed percentage of the optimal water supply. The reduction was performed by increasing the time intervals between irrigations rather than by changing the irrigation volume. The yield data sets are complemented by data sets containing climate data (temperature, radiation, rain volume) and information on the cultivation times. Further experimental details, cultivar names and data analysis are provided in the paper 'Assessment of drought tolerance and its potential yield penalty in potato' in Functional Plant Biology, 2015, 42, 655–667, http://dx.doi.org/10.1071/FP15013.
keywords: controlled environments, drought tolerance, Solanum tuberosum, phenotyping, abiotic stress

name: Quantitative monitoring of nucleotide information from genetic resources in context of their citation in the scientific literature

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description:
This data set comprise extracted and linked records of the European Nucleotide Archive to citations in open-access publications that aggregated at Europe PubMed Central. Doing so, ENA records were parsed and filtered for valid country tag and fed into ePMC RestFull API to extract matching secondary publication by ENA accession or project accession numbers. The resulting data sets are normalized as tables ENA_SEQUENCES, PMC_REFERENCES alongside a curated list of world's countries in table CONTRIES and economics groups in table COUNTRY2GRP. This tables are the basis for a data warehouse and a web application 
It enables to join literature and sequence databases in multidimensional fashion. A concrete use case in the context of the United Nations convention on Biological Diversity is the analysis of countries in respect of nucleotide sequence use and contribution.
keywords: data citation, text mining, European Nucleotide Archive, nucleotide sequence data, Convention on Biological Diversity, Europe PMC

name: INTERMEDIUM-C mediates the shade-induced bud growth arrest in barley

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description:
Tiller formation is a key agronomic determinant for grain yield in cereal crops. The modulation of this trait is controlled by transcriptional regulators and plant hormones, tightly regulated by external environmental conditions. While endogenous (genetic) and exogenous (environmental factors) triggers for tiller formation have mostly been investigated separately, it has remained elusive how they are integrated into the developmental program of this trait. The transcription factor INTERMEDIUM-C (INT-C), which is the barley ortholog of the maize domestication gene TEOSINTE BRANCHED1 (TB1) has a prominent role in regulating tiller bud outgrowth. Here we show that INT-C is expressed in tiller buds, required for bud growth arrest in response to shade. In contrast to wild type plants, int-c mutant plants are impaired in their shade response and do not stop tiller production after shading. Gene expression levels of INT-C are up-regulated under light-limiting growth conditions, and down-regulated after decapitation. Transcriptome analysis of wild-type and int-c buds under control and shading conditions identified target genes of INT-C that belong to auxin and gibberellin biosynthesis and signaling pathways. Our study identifies INT-C as integrator of the shade response into tiller formation, which is prerequisite for implementing shading responses in the breeding of cereal crops.
Here the related transcriptome data derived from a custom-synthesized 60 k Barley Microarray (Agilent Technologies) (Koppolu et al., 2013) is published.
For detailed information and sample composition please see the readme file.
keywords: INTERMEDIUM-C, yield, barley, bud growth arrest, shade avoidance, decapitation, absisic acid

name: Hordeum spontaneum
Simulation of chromosome condensation with loop extruders and centromeric nucleosomes (high resolution version).

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description:
This dataset contains four movies showing the condensation of a chromosome with centromeric nucleosomes via loop extrusion. In this new version the movies have a higher resolution than in the previous dataset (DOI:10.5447/ipk/2021/5).

HolocentricChromosome_noEffectCentromeres.mp4 - Condensation of a holocentric chromosome, where the centromeric nucleosomes have no effect on the Loop Extruders. Three visualization modes are present. Chromatin is shown as a 10 nm thick grey fibre, the Loop Extruders are represented by the bound nucleosomes as pairs of yellow beads and the centromeric nucleosomes are shown as beads coloured in red or in a gradient from blue to red, following their chromosome position, as indicated by the subtitles. The simulation presents 1000 LEs and 100 centromeric nucleosomes.

HolocentricChromosome_blockingCentromeres.mp4 - Condensation of a holocentric chromosome, where the centromeric nucleosomes have a blocking effect on the Loop Extruders. Three visualization modes are present. Chromatin is shown as a 10 nm thick grey fibre, the Loop Extruders are represented by the bound nucleosomes as pairs of yellow beads and the centromeric nucleosomes are shown as beads coloured in red or in a gradient from blue to red, following their chromosome position, as indicated by the subtitles. The simulation presents 1000 LEs and 100 centromeric nucleosomes.

HolocentricChromosome_anchoringCentromeres.mp4 - Condensation of a holocentric chromosome, where the centromeric nucleosomes have an anchoring effect on the Loop Extruders. Three visualization modes are present. Chromatin is shown as a 10 nm thick grey fibre, the Loop Extruders are represented by the bound nucleosomes as pairs of yellow beads and the centromeric nucleosomes are shown as beads coloured in red or in a gradient from blue to red, following their chromosome position, as indicated by the subtitles. The simulation presents 1000 LEs and 100 centromeric nucleosomes.

MonocentricChromosome_anchoringCentromeres.mp4 - Condensation of a monocentric chromosome, where the centromeric nucleosomes have an anchoring effect on the Loop Extruders. Three visualization modes are present. Chromatin is shown as a 10 nm thick grey fibre, the Loop Extruders are represented by the bound nucleosomes as pairs of yellow beads and the centromeric nucleosomes are shown as beads coloured in red or in a gradient from blue to red, following their chromosome position, as indicated by the subtitles. The simulation presents 1000 LEs and 20 centromeric nucleosomes
keywords: polymer simulation, chromosome condensation, loop extrusion, centromere organization

description: RNA was extracted from seedlings of Aegilops sharonensis accession 1644 at the three-leaf stage. name: Annotated resistance gene enrichment sequencing (RenSeq) assemblies of a winter wheat diversity panel

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: RenSeq assemblies of 907 diverse T. aestivum genotypes and two control genotypes. The assemblies were generated using CLC assembler (https://digitalinsights.qiagen.com/products-overview/discovery-insights-portfolio/analysis-and-visualization/qiagen-clc-assembly-cell/). The contigs from each accession were annotated with AUGUSTUS v3.3.1 using wheat gene models as training datasets and contigs with complete genes were identified. Amino acid (AA), coding sequence (CDS) and transcript sequence for each complete gene was extracted using getAnnoFasta.pl script from AUGUSTUS package. The files ending with “_updated_fasta” is the direct output of CLC assembler and contains contigs from each accession.  The files ending with “_updated_complete.gff”, “_updated_complete.mrna”, “_updated_complete.aa” and  “_updated_complete.codingseq” contain gene information in GFF3 format, transcript sequences, amino acid sequences and coding sequences respectively from each accession. Passport data and/or pedigree information and BioSamples IDs of RenSeq raw data are provided in the sample information file.
keywords: Triticum aestivum, wheat, resistance gene, sequence assembly, RenSeq, annotation, diversity panel

name: Projection-based gene annotation of barley genotype Hatiexi

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: The chromosome-scale genome sequence assembly of barley (Hordeum vulgare L.) genotype Hatiexi was annotated using the projection-approach of Jayakodi et al. (DOI:10.1038/s41586-020-2947-8). High-confidence gene models of the MorexV3 genome assembly (DOI:10.5447/ipk/2021/3) were projected to the Hatiexi assembly, which has been deposited at the European Nucleotide Archive under accession PRJEB47552. The annotation is provided in General Feature Format (GFF). Coding sequences and protein sequences are provided in FASTA format.
keywords: barley, Hordeum vulgare, genome, annotation, gene model projection

name: Hordeum spontaneum
Unravel metabolic patterns and molecular mechanisms underlying storability in sugar beet

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description:
Targeted and untargeted metabolic profiling of polar and semi-polar metabolites in extracts from freeze-dried sugar beet (Beta vulgaris L.) roots from six different varieties; V1-6. The analysis was performed via RP-UPLC-PDA-FLR (reverse phase ultra-performance liquid chromatography coupled to photodiode array detector and to fluorescence detector) and RP-UPLC-PDA-ESI-QTOF-MS and -MS/MS (reverse phase ultra-performance liquid chromatography coupled to photodiode array detector and to electrospray quadrupole time-of-flight tandem mass spectrometry).
The raw data files of metabolite analysis comprise:
-	“0_Metadata and methods” which contains three .txt documents describing the materials and methods of free amino acid, organic acids, and semi-polar metabolite analysis, as well as two .csv documents including metadata and metainformation. In these files, sample names, reagents, method details, as well as species, harvest dates and the CSFID from Madritsch et al., 2020 (https://doi.org/10.1007/s11103-020-01041-8) can be found.
-	“1_Free amino acids” including three .csv documents with the raw data, the evaluation, and the summary of free amino acid analysis.
-	“2_Organic acids” which contains four folders with raw LC-MS and -MSMS data including washes, blanks, standards, and samples. Also, it contains three .csv documents with the raw data, the evaluation, and the summary of organic acid analysis.
-	“3_Semi-polar compounds” including two folders with raw LC-MSMS data, as well as three .csv documents with the raw data, the evaluation, and the summary of semi-polar metabolite analysis.
This work was funded by the Austrian Research Promotion Agency (FFG), grant number 855706.
keywords: Free amino acids, Organic acids, Semi-polar metabolites, LC-MS, Sugar beet, Metabolomics

name: LIDAR-based phenotyping of potato shoot development under drought stress

publisher.name: Leibniz Institute of Plant Genetics and Crop Plant Research (IPK), Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: In a drought stress trial, 64 Solanum tuberosum ssp tuberosum genotypes from a population segregating for drought tolerance were phenotyped with a Planteye(Phenospex)-LIDAR (light detection and ranging) system. The population had been characterized for drought tolerance based on the relative tuber starch yield in different container systems and field trials under typical Central European drought scenarios (K. Köhl (2018-12-11): Selection and validation experiment comparing phenotypic and marker-assisted selection for drought tolerance in Solanum tuberosum ssp. tuberosum. DOI:10.5447/ipk/2020/18). Drought stress (S) was imposed by reducing the total volume of irrigation to 50 % of the optimal volume (C). For the LIDAR measurements, plants were cultivated under naturally fluctuating climate conditions in a polytunnel. In vitro propagated cuttings were planted in bigbags with 30 l peat-based substrate on 9.04.2015 or 13.04 2016. The measurements were performed between 22 and 61 days after planting (DFP) in 2015 and between 5 and 75 DFP in 2016. The useful range of measurements was restricted by inaccurate plant detection at the beginning and lodging and intermingling of shoot after flowering.
keywords: Phenotyping, Potato, LIDAR, Drought tolerance, Fluctuating environment

name: Helical organization of barley metaphase chromatids

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description:
This dataset contains eleven movies supporting the helical organization of metaphase chromatids. They are movies from microscopy images, polymer simulations and HiC analysis.

Hi-C_sliding_window_analysis.mp4: Bump position along chromosome 5H indicating the turn sizes. Placement of the bump calculated for 119 different positions in the sequence of chromosome 5H separated by 5 Mb.
Polymer_simulation_model.mp4: Polymer simulation model for a single FISH labelled 5H chromatid.
FISH_1.avi: The 14 somatic barley metaphase chromosomes labelled by FISH. The movie shows clearly that the oligo-FISH labelled 5HL region is also labelled inside of the chromosome arms.
FISH_2.mp4: The slices of a chromosome 5H SIM image stack shown in ortho fiew indicate the complete FISH labelling of the inner chromatin.
FISH_3.avi: Spatial minor chromatin fiber intermingling of the adjacent chromonema turns at chromosome arm 5HL labelled in different solors by oligo-FISH.
FISH_4.mp4: The spatial surface rendering of chromosome 5H displays that the FISH signals are present within the whole chromosome volume.
FISH_5.mp4: Spatial arrangements of telomeres and subtelomeres.
Chromatin_structure-no_cavities_1.avi: The single SIM image stack slices of a DAPI-labelled 6H chromosome show a network of minor ~80 nm looped chromatin fibers free of large cavities throughtout the chromosome arms. Within centromere and NOR straight ~80 nm chromatin fibers occur.
Chromatin_structure-no_cavities_2.avi.mp4: Spatial organization of the same 6H chromosome shown in the previous movie.
SCEs_1.mp4: Spatial arrangement of the oligo-FISH and EdU labelled region of a 5H chromosome,
SCEs_2.mp4: Spatial arrangement of the oligo-FISH and EdU labelled region of a 5H chromosome.
keywords: Chromosome helical coiling, Chromosome conformation capture sequencing, Polymer modelling, Barley metaphase chromosomes, Oligo-fluorescence in situ hybridization (oligo-FISH), Structured illumnation microscopy (SIM)

name: Hordeum spontaneum
Genome-wide association mapping for yellow rust resistance in a population of 454 whole-genome sequenced diverse wheat genotypes

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: Yellow rust infections were evaluated in seven different field experiments based on natural or artificial inoculations and using a 1-to-9 scoring scale [1: complete absence of symptoms, 9: severe infection]. Best linear unbiased estimators (BLUEs) across experiments were used as phenotypes for genome-wide association studies (GWAS). GWAS was conducted for 454 whole-genome sequenced (WGS) wheat genotypes considering a kinship matrix computed from genotyping-by-sequencing (GBS) markers. SNP-based GWAS was conducted using WGS variants mapped to Chinese Spring (RefSeq v1.0) while k-mer-based GWAS was performed using the presence/absence of 31-bp-long sequence motifs. For further details on input files and R codes, please read the “README.txt” files.
keywords: yellow rust (Puccinia striiformis f. sp. tritici ), wheat (Triticum aestivum L.), field inoculations, best linear unbiased estimate (BLUE), genome-wide association study (GWAS), genotyping-by-sequencing (GBS), whole-genome sequencing (WGS), SNP, k-mers

name: Triticum vulgare
Genomic prediction of yield breeding values for 10,353 winter wheat genebank samples

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: Genotyping-by-sequencing (GBS) was used to characterize 7,745 genebank samples from the German Federal ex situ winter wheat collection (IPK genebank) plus 325 European elite cultivars. GBS variants are according to the reference genome of Chinese Spring (RefSeq v1.0). Genetic distances were computed among these 8,070 GBS samples. Among IPK genebank samples, 597 have breeding value estimates for grain yield (Mg/ha on a 140 g H2O per harvested kg moisture basis) and served as training set for genomic predictions of all IPK genebank samples. This training set allowed also genomic predictions for 2,608 accessions of the French winter wheat collection (INRAE genebank) by integrating GBS and previously published molecular data (https://doi.org/10.1126/sciadv.aav0536). Genomic predictions and their standard errors were computed using the genomic best linear unbiased prediction (GBLUP) method. For further details on input files and R codes, please read the “README.txt” files.
keywords: wheat (Triticum aestivum L.), genotyping-by-sequencing (GBS), genetic distances, yield breeding value, genomic best linear unbiased prediction (GBLUP), German and French genebanks

name: Variant matrices for six-rowed wild-growing barleys (Hordeum agriocrithon)

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: Single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) matrices for six-rowed wild-growing barley (Hordeum vulgare subsp. agriocrithon), two-rowed wild barley (Hordeum vulgare spp. spontaneum) and domesticated barley. SNP matrices in Variant Call Format (VCF) were constructed from whole-genome shotgun (WGS) data or genotyping-by-sequencing data (GBS). VCF files for WGS data are provided for two coverage levels (3x and 10x). The 3x matrix was derived from downsampled data to ensure equal read depth across samples. The MorexV3 reference genome sequence assembly of barley cv. Morex (Mascher et al. 2021, https://doi.org/10.1093/plcell/koab077) was used as a reference for read mapping and variant calling. VCF files were compressed with BGZIP to allow for indexing with tabix. Samples (columns in the VCF files) are referred to by the EMBL ENA accession ID of their WGS or GBS reads. Further information on the identity and provenance of sequenced samples is provided in the three CSV files.
keywords: barley, Hordeum vulgare, whole genome shotgun sequencing, genotyping-by-sequencing, variant matrix, plant genetic resources

name: Hordeum spontaneum
Comparison of ten genomic prediction approaches in a diverse collection of plant genetic resources in wheat

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: Ten different genomic prediction models were implemented and the associated quality of prediction was compared based on prediction ability. A set of 7745 single-seed-decent lines, which originated from 7651 accessions of wheat, were included in the study with genotyping-by-sequencing data and adjusted entry means of four traits (flowering time, plant height, thousand grain weight, yellow rust resistance). The implementation of the ten models for genomic prediction in R is presented together with an example dataset for the trait plant height. Predictions of the four traits with the most accurate model are also given as a  table.
keywords: genomic prediction, wheat, plant genetic resources, flowering time, plant height, thousand grain weight, yellow rust resistance

name: Triticum vulgare
Identification of proteins taking part in N and water deficiency response in potato

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description:
The dataset comprise the result of protein profiling of four potato cultivars 'Tomb', 'Eurostarch', 'Kolibri' and 'Kiebitz' cultivated under singly applied N or water deficiency as well as under combination of both stressors. Peptides were analysed by LC/MS, using Dionex UltiMate(TM) 3000 RSLCnano System (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Dreieich, Germany) coupled to an Impact II (Bruker Daltonics, Bremen, Germany). Raw data files of the LC-MS measurement and protein identification: 
1.The Bruker Impact II LC/MS raw data files of the protein profiling of singly applied N or water deficiency;2.The Bruker Impact II LC/MS raw data files of the protein profiling of combined N and water deficiency; 3.Proteins identification and quantification obtained using Mascot v2.5.1 and Progenesis QI for proteomics (Version 3.0)
keywords: potato, proteomics, nitrogen deficiency, drought

name: Training course material for the course 'de.NBI Biology meets Programming - Introduction to Bioinformatics using Python'

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description:
In the post-genomic era, every biologist is faced with the task of analyzing, interpreting and visualizing complex and huge data. An increasing number of scientists have begun writing small programs using script-based languages, such as Python. This course is designed to train students and scientists without previous experience in programming who want -- or need -- to write their own bioinformatics software tools. The aim of this training course is to provide an introduction to the Python programming language by solving everyday tasks of Bioinformatics. Each folder contains a short introduction video and a PDF file about the topic, assignments covering the topic (provided as Jupyter notebooks) as well as the solutions (provided as Python files).

Please first read the content of the file 'readme.pdf' and follow the course plan according to the content of the file 'course_plan.pdf'.

Please cite the authors for all course material if you use them in your work.
keywords: Python, de.NBI, training course

name: Unraveling metabolic patterns and molecular mechanisms underlying storability in sugar beet

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: Targeted and untargeted metabolic profiling of polar and semi-polar metabolites in extracts from freeze-dried sugar beet (Beta vulgaris L.) roots from six different varieties; V1-6. The analysis was performed via RP-UPLC-PDA-FLR (reverse phase ultra-performance liquid chromatography coupled to photodiode array detector and to fluorescence detector) and RP-UPLC-PDA-ESI-QTOF-MS and -MS/MS (reverse phase ultra-performance liquid chromatography coupled to photodiode array detector and to electrospray quadrupole time-of-flight tandem mass spectrometry). The raw data files of metabolite analysis comprise: - “0_Metadata and methods” which contains three .txt documents describing the materials and methods of free amino acid, organic acids, and semi-polar metabolite analysis, as well as two .csv documents including metadata and metainformation. In these files, sample names, reagents, method details, as well as species, harvest dates and the CSFID from Madritsch et al., 2020 (https://doi.org/10.1007/s11103-020-01041-8) can be found. - “1_Free amino acids” including three .csv documents with the raw data, the evaluation, and the summary of free amino acid analysis. - “2_Organic acids” which contains four folders with raw LC-MS and -MSMS data including washes, blanks, standards, and samples. Also, it contains three .csv documents with the raw data, the evaluation, and the summary of organic acid analysis. - “3_Semi-polar compounds” including two folders with raw LC-MSMS data, as well as three .csv documents with the raw data, the evaluation, and the summary of semi-polar metabolite analysis. This work was funded by the Austrian Research Promotion Agency (FFG), grant number 855706.
keywords: Free amino acids, Organic acids, Semi-polar metabolites, LC-MS, Sugar beet, Metabolomics

name: Triticum vulgare
Metabolite profile in root exudates of catch crops under different cultivation conditions

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: Plants release a variety of metabolites through their roots that influence physicochemical properties and biological processes in the rhizosphere. While hydroponic growing conditions allow easy accessibility of the root system and extraction of root exudates, the natural soil environment can alter root metabolism and exudate secretion. We studied root exudates from four taxonomically distant cover crop species, namely white mustard, lacy phacelia, bristle oat, and Egyptian clover, using a root washing method in the field and compared targeted and untargeted metabolite profiles with exudates from hydroponically cultivated plants. We found that hydroponically cultivated plants released a greater amount of total carbon, but that total carbon recovery was not indicative of metabolite diversity in root exudates. The composition of secondary metabolites was much more pronounced than that of quantified primary metabolites in all species and growth conditions. Among the secondary metabolite classes, the presence of lipids and lipid-like molecules was very characteristic for the field samples, while the release of a large amount of phenylpropanoids, organoheterocyclic compounds or benzoids was characteristic for clover, mustard and oat, respectively, regardless of the growing conditions. However, at the compound level, the majority of metabolites released were specific to the growing conditions for each species, implying that hydroponically sampled root exudates poorly reflect the metabolic complexity of root exudates from field-grown plants.
keywords: Root exudates, untargeted metabolite profile, primary metabolites, secondary metabolites, Sinapis alba, Avena strigosa, Phacelia tanacetifolia, Trifolium alexandrinum, root washing, hydroponics
