name: Genomic-phenotypic data interoperability between 8,838 genotyped wheat samples, grain yield breeding value estimates and yellow rust infection scores from multiple-environment field trials

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: Genotyping-by-sequencing (GBS) was performed for 7,745 accession samples from the German Federal ex situ winter wheat collection (IPK genebank) plus 325 European elite cultivars. Whole genome sequencing (WGS) was conducted using 3-fold coverage for 446 IPK accession samples, 191 European elite cultivars and 131 German elite breeding lines. Variant calling was performed according to the reference genome of Chinese Spring (RefSeq v1.0). Roger’s distances were computed among GBS and WGS samples and a Mantel’s test was performed among common genotypes between platforms. A total of 6,371 GBS and 309 WGS samples have best linear unbiased estimates (BLUEs) for yellow rust (YR) scores from a large-scale multiple-environment resistance screening based on natural infections and using a 1-to-9 scoring scale (1: complete absence of symptoms, 9: severe infected plants). A set of 799 GBS and 454 WGS samples have BLUEs for YR scores (1-to-9 scale) from precise multiple-environment field resistance characterizations based on artificial and natural infections. Among GBS samples of genebank accessions, 597 have breeding values for grain yield (Mg/ha on a 14% moisture basis) estimated from F1 crosses with adapted elite cultivars and tested in multiple-environments. The genomic-phenotypic data interoperability was computed for each trait and genomic platform as the correlation between genomic predicted and observed values in 100 runs of five-fold cross validations; normalized afterwards with the square root of heritability. Genomic predictions were computed using the genomic best linear unbiased prediction (GBLUP) method. For further details on data, R codes and their outputs, please read the “README.txt” files.
keywords: wheat (Triticum aestivum L.), genebank plant material, elite modern cultivars and lines, genotyping-by-sequencing (GBS), whole genome sequencing (WGS), yellow rust (Puccinia striiformis f. sp. tritici ), disease resistance scoring, yield breeding value, data interoperability, genetic distances, Mantel's test, cross-validations, genomic best linear unbiased prediction (GBLUP)

name: Triticum vulgare
Multiple-environment yield evaluation of 173 advanced wheat pre-breeding lines from crosses involving IPK genebank accessions with high yield breeding values

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: In hybrids between modern cultivars and plant genetic resources (PGR), the elite background compensates for the lack of adaptation of PGR, allowing thus the estimation of the yield breeding value of PGR. Thirteen PGR from the German Federal ex situ winter wheat collection (IPK genebank) were preliminary selected for their high breeding values and used as parents in 32 initial crosses involving one to two locally adapted European cultivars. After two generations of selfing and plant material depuration in 0.5 m2 plots, at least one progeny per initial cross could enter early yield testing experiments. In total, 173 F3:4 progenies were tested for their yield performance together with 15 elite cultivar checks and 16 additional pre-breeding lines. Seven additional entries (coded as 'LSA_1-7') present in early yield experiments were lines from the State Plant Breeding Institute of the University of Hohenheim. Four partially overlapping yield experiments were conducted using conventional agricultural practices under local rainfed conditions during harvest years 2020 and 2021 at two German locations. Three elite cultivar checks connected the four experiments. In each experiment, the experimental unit was a 6 m2 plot, while spatial variation on yield was accounted and corrected using incomplete blocks. Plot yields were expressed in Mg/ha on a 14% moisture basis and are available in ISA-Tab format. An R code for the computation of heritabilities and best linear unbiased estimations of yield performance as well as its expected outputs are also provided.
keywords: wheat (Triticum aestivum L.), informed pre-breeding, plant genetic resources, yield breeding values, elite modern cultivars, yield, multiple-environment field experiments

name: Triticum vulgare
Evaluating the yellow rust resistance of 600 winter wheat IPK genebank accession samples and 199 modern European cultivars based on natural and artificial inoculations in multiple-environments

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: Puccinia striiformis f. sp. tritici is the causal agent of yellow rust (YR). This wheat disease causes severe yield losses and its recent pandemics broke down several resistance genes that are widely deployed in modern cultivars. New resistance sources could be provided by plant genetic resources (PGR) stored at genebanks. Three diverse trait-customized core-collections (T3Cs) targeting YR and two other important wheat diseases were selected based on preliminary genomic and phenotypic characterizations of PGR stored at the German Federal ex situ winter wheat collection (IPK genebank). Seven experiments were conducted to precisely evaluate the 600 diverse PGR samples from T3Cs plus 200 diverse modern European cultivars for their resistance against YR. Experiments were conducted under rainfed conditions during harvest years 2019 and 2020 at four German locations. Two experiments were based on natural infections, while the other five experiments were artificially inoculated. Excepting one experiment, in which incomplete blocks were considered, an alpha lattice design was used in all other experiments. The size of the experimental unit (plot) was location specific and ranged between 0.2 and 0.5 m2. Fungicide use was avoided in all experiments, while herbicides and/or fertilizers were applied according to local crop management. In each experiment, either two (early and late) or a single timepoint(s) were considered for the assessment of resistance. Across experiments, mislabeling of one modern cultivar was confirmed. Infection severity was expressed in a 1 (no symptoms) to 9 (severe infection) scoring scale. YR infections retained after outlier correction are available here in ISA-Tab format. An R code for the computation of heritabilities and best linear unbiased estimations of YR infection scorings as well as its expected outputs are also provided.
keywords: wheat (Triticum aestivum L.), yellow rust (Puccinia striiformis f. sp. tritici ), plant genetic resources, trait-customized core-collections, elite modern cultivars, field inoculations, natural infections, multiple-environment field experiments

name: Triticum vulgare
Evaluating the yellow rust resistance of 7,682 winter wheat IPK genebank accessions and 80 modern European cultivars based on natural infections in multiple-environments

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: Puccinia striiformis f. sp. tritici is the causal agent of yellow rust (YR). This wheat disease causes severe yield losses and its recent pandemics broke down several resistance genes that are widely deployed in modern cultivars. New resistance sources could be provided by plant genetic resources (PGR) stored at genebanks. Twelve field experiments were conducted to large-scale screen the resistance against natural occurring YR of 7,684 PGR from the German Federal ex situ winter wheat collection (IPK genebank) and 80 modern European elite cultivars. Experiments were conducted under rainfed conditions between harvest years 2015 and 2020 at two German locations. Across experiments, plant material was tested in an unorthogonal fashion, with each experiment considering 1,428 to 1,697 entries. Experiments were performed following an alpha lattice design and considering a 0.4 m2 plot as experimental unit. In all experiments, weed control was based on herbicides and neither fungicides nor nitrogen fertilizers were applied. YR infection severity was manually scored according to a 1 (no symptoms) to 9 (severe infection) scoring scale. After outlier correction, YR infections for 7,682 PGR and 80 European elite cultivars were retained and are available here in ISA-Tab format. An R code for the computation of heritabilities and best linear unbiased estimations of YR infection scorings as well as its expected outputs are also provided.
keywords: wheat (Triticum aestivum L.), yellow rust (Puccinia striiformis f. sp. tritici ), plant genetic resources, large-scale screening, elite modern cultivars, natural infections, multiple-environment field experiments

name: Triticum vulgare
Estimating the breeding values of 707 winter wheat IPK genebank accessions using yields of 'Elite×PGR' F1 hybrids tested across multiple-environment experiments

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: In F1 hybrids between modern cultivars and plant genetic resources (PGR), i.e. 'Elite×PGR' crosses, the elite background compensates for the lack of adaptation of PGR, allowing thus the estimation of the yield breeding value of PGR. Seven hundred seven diverse PGR from the German Federal ex situ winter wheat collection (IPK genebank) were crossed as male parents with 36 elite cultivars in an incomplete factorial fashion to produce a total of 1,429 'Elite×PGR' hybrids. Hybrid seed production was performed using chemical hybridizing agents. These hybrids together with additional plant material were tested for their yield performance in 6-9 m2 plots across 22 multiple-environment experiments. Experiments were conducted following an alpha lattice design and using conventional agricultural practices under local rainfed conditions between harvest years 2016 and 2020 in seven German locations. Plot yields were expressed in Mg/ha on a 14% moisture basis, corrected for outliers and adjusted for experimental design effects. Yield records of 1,429 'Elite×PGR' hybrids together with four 'Elite1×Elite2' hybrids and 264 parent lines are available in ISA-Tab format. An R code for the computation of heritabilities and yield breeding values as well as its expected outputs are also provided.
keywords: wheat (Triticum aestivum L.), plant genetic resources, yield breeding value estimation, elite modern cultivars, F1 'Elite×PGR' hybrid crosses, multiple-environment field experiments

name: Triticum vulgare
Long read genome assembly, gene and tRNA annotation of the tropical legume Lablab purpureus.

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: The data includes the fasta file for the 11 assembled pseudomolecules, the fasta files for gene cds and peptide sequences as well as GFF annotation files for genes and tRNAs. In the case of more than one splice variant per gene locus the longest cds was used as representative gene model. The results described in the bioRxiv preprint 'Chromosome-scale assembly of the lablab genome - A model for inclusive orphan crop genomics' (https://doi.org/10.1101/2022.05.08.491073) are based on this data set. Data management and annotation was supported by de.NBI (www.denbi.de, 031A536, German Ministry of Education and Research).
keywords: Lablab purpureus, orphan crop, genome sequence assembly, long read sequencing, gene annotation, collaboration, bioinformatic capacity building

name: Metabolic diversity in a collection of wild and cultivated Brassica rapa subspecies

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: Brassica rapa (B. rapa) and its subspecies contain many bioactive metabolites that are important for plant defense and human health. This study aimed at investigating the metabolite composition and variation among a large collection of B. rapa genotypes including subspecies and their accessions. Metabolite profiling of leaves of 102 B. rapa genotypes was performed using ultra-performance liquid chromatography coupled with photodiode array detector and quadrupole time-of-flight mass spectrometry (UPLC-PDA-QTOF-MS/MS). In total 346 metabolites belonging to different chemical classes were tentatively identified; 36 out of them were assigned with high confidence using authentic standards and 184 were those reported in B. rapa leaves for the first time. The accumulation and variation of metabolites among genotypes were characterized and compared to their phylogenetic distance. We found 47 metabolites, mostly representing anthocyanins, flavonols and hydroxycinnamic acid derivatives that displayed a significant correlation to the phylogenetic relatedness and determined four major phylometabolic branches; (a) Chinese cabbage, (b) yellow sarson and rapid cycling, (c) the mizuna-komatsuna-turnip-caitai; and (d) a mixed cluster. These metabolites denote the selective pressure on metabolic network during B. rapa breeding. We present a unique study that combines metabolite profiling data with phylogenetic analysis in a large collection of B. rapa subspecies. We show how selective breeding utilize the biochemical potential of wild B. rapa leading to highly diverse metabolic phenotypes. Our work provides the basis for further studies on B. rapa metabolism and nutritional traits improvement
keywords: Brassica rapa, metabolite profiling, mass spectrometry, specialized metabolism, selective breeding

name: GLOBAL STRATEGY FOR THE CONSERVATION OF POTATO

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: Cultivated potato, Solanum tuberosum ssp. tuberosum, is the third most consumed crop globally and important not only for food but also for for the animal feed, pharmaceutical, textile and paper industries. To gain an overview on the current state of the conservation and use of potato genetic resources, the Global Crop Diversity Trust (Crop Trust), commissioned an update of the ‘Global conservation strategy for potato genetic resources’. This updated strategy aims to support the efficiency and effectiveness of potato diversity conservation at national, regional and international levels, and to identify priorities for strengthening the conservation and use of potato genetic resources.
keywords: ex situ conservation, plant genetic resources, potato, Solanum tuberosum, global strategy, conservation strategy, wild potato, Andigenum group, Chilotanum group, native potato variety, genebank, accession, true potato seed, potato tuber, late blight

name: Passport information for 8,838 genotyped wheat samples

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: Genotyping-by-sequencing was performed for 7,745 accession samples from the German Federal ex situ winter wheat collection (IPK genebank) plus 325 European elite cultivars. Whole genome sequencing was conducted using 3-fold coverage for 446 IPK accession samples, 191 European elite cultivars and 131 German elite breeding lines. Sequenced genotypes are findable through the ‘SAMEA’ BioSample IDs on EMBL-EBI BioSamples (https://www.ebi.ac.uk/biosamples/). ‘SAMEA’ IDs were integrated with plant material passports collected in Schulthess et al. (2022, https://doi.org/10.1038/s41588-022-01189-7). Passports of ‘TRI’ accessions were accessed through the IPK Genebank Information System as extended MCPD-format. Passports of ‘B’ accessions as well as those for elite cultivars and breeding lines were compiled from different sources. Passports include scientific name, geographical origin, growth habit, year of acquisition/release/obtention, and source of passport data. Digital object identifiers (DOIs) of ‘TRI’ accessions and their in-field isolated samples are also included. For further details please read the “README.txt” file.
keywords: wheat (Triticum aestivum L.), SAMEA BioSamples, genotyping-by-sequencing, whole genome sequencing, passport information, plant genetic resources, elite modern cultivars, elite breeding lines, digital object identifiers (DOI) of genebank accessions

name: Triticum vulgare
Powdery mildew resistance phenotyping of the winter wheat collection of the German Federal ex situ Genebank for Agricultural and Horticultural Crops at IPK Gatersleben

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: The here published data were gathered in the frame of the GeneBank2.0 Project (Grant Nos. FKZ031B0184B and FKZ031B0184A). They contain phenotypic information of Powdery Mildew Resistance (Blumeria graminis f. sp. Tritici isolate FAL 92315) of 7,398 plant genetic resources as well as 154 European elite cultivars produced under controlled environment conditions using a semiautomatic detached-leaf-assay-plus-imaging platform (Macrobot). The repository contains the gathered phenotypic data as well as metadata of the experimental setup and inoculation conditions in the ISA-TAB format. In addition to that, we provide the original images of the conducted detached leaf assays in .PNG format. An R script to curate the phenotypic data and compute best linear unbiased estimations (BLUEs) - ready-to-use phenotypic values - is also included.
keywords: Powdery Mildew, Phenotyping, Wheat, Resistance, Detached leaf assay, Microphenomics, Image analysis

name: Triticum vulgare
De-novo assembled genotyping-by-sequencing (GBS) datasets for Crocus series Verni species

publisher.name: Leibniz Institute of Plant Genetics and Crop Plant Research (IPK), Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: De-novo assembled genotyping-by-sequencing (GBS) datasets for Crocus series Verni species. GBS was performed for 194 samples including plants from 63 populations: 24 C. heuffelianus/C. cf. heuffelianus, 13 C. vernus/C. cf. vernus, nine C. tommasinianus, three C. bertiscensis, three C. neapolitanus, two C. neglectus, two C. kosaninii, one C. siculus and one C. neglectus, two populations of outgroup C. malyi, and one ornamental cultivar (C. etrucus cv. 'Zwanenburg'). Four different files are provided: Dataset S1: An alignment of 2009 concatenated GBS loci in nexus format (.nex) for all samples; Dataset S2: A variant calling format (.vcf) file excluding the outgroup C. malyi with 30,661 single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP); Dataset S3: An EIGENSTRAT (.geno) file of 2172 unlinked SNPs; Dataset S4: A RADpainter file based on 10,591 loci. Dataset S1 to S3 were generated by IPYRAD v.0.9.58, dataset S4 was generated by STACKS v2.55. Information on plant material is provided in a separat table. The analyzed raw reads are available through ENA study accession number PRJEB57934.
keywords: GBS, Crocus series Verni

name: Data record for the genomic resources of cultivated European two-rowed spring barley genotypes

publisher.name: Leibniz Institute of Plant Genetics and Crop Plant Research (IPK), Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description:
RNA-sequencing data and variant call files from a collection of 209 different European two-rowed barley genotypes. The RNA-sequencing data came from six different tissues across a range of barley developmental stages: crown, root, inflorescence, peduncle, spikelet and grain. Reads were mapped against a barley reference transcriptome BaRTv2 (Coulter et al., 2022; doi:10.1111/tpj.15871) using Salmon (Patro et al., 2017; doi:10.1038/nmeth.4197). For each tissue one file containing the raw count and one file containing the transcripts per million (TPM) values are given in the folder “Gene_expression”.

Variant calling of single nucleotide polymorphisms was done on the RNA-sequencing data from the six different tissues mentioned above and shallow 2x coverage whole genome shotgun sequencing (WGS). Raw reads were mapped against the Barke reference genome (Jayakodi et al., 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2947-8) using STAR (Dobin et al., 2013; doi:10.1093/bioinformatics/bts635). Variant calling of insertions or deletions (Indels) was done using the RNA-sequencing data from the six different tissues using the same Barke reference genome. Annotation was added using SnpEff (Cingolani et al., 2012; doi:10.4161/fly.19695).

Two files one containing the SNP information and the other the Indel information are given in the folder “Variant_identification”.

Raw data files are available through the European Nucleotide Archive under the following project numbers: PRJEB49069 (RNA-seq) / PRJEB48903 (WGS).
keywords: barley, gene expression, genomic marker, single nucleotide polymorphism, two-rowed, spring, European barley germplasm

name: Phenotyping shoot growth in potato under short-term and long-term drought stress

publisher.name: Leibniz Institute of Plant Genetics and Crop Plant Research (IPK), Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: Twenty potato genotypes  were grown in three experiments under optimal water supply (cc),  early (sc), late (cs) and long-term (ss) drought stress in bigbag containers under variable light conditions in the polytunnel screenhouse of the MPI of Molecular Plant Physiology at Potsdam-Golm, Germany ((52°23′55″ N 13°3′56″ E). Meteorological conditions were continuously measured on a weather station next to the experiment. Soil water content and temperature were measured with PlantCare™ soil sensors every 60 min. Plants were irrigated with an injector-drip irrigation system with defined water volumes every three to four days. Plants on stress treatment received water with half the frequency of the optimally watered plants. Shoot development was monitored with two Planteye F400 laser scanners mounted on an automobile Fieldscan device. The system yielded six 3d-point clouds per day for each plant. Data were subsequently evaluated with the Hortcontrol software, which estimated plant height, digital biomass, leaf area, projected leaf area, leaf area index, light penetration depth, leaf angle and leaf inclination. At a thermal time of approximately 1400 °CD, the haulm was removed and tubers were harvested. Tuber number in three size groups, tuber fresh weight and starch yield were determined for each plant.
keywords: Solanum tuberosum ssp tuberosum, Phenomics, Drought stress, Abiotic stress

name: Introgression prediction for wheat genebank collections

publisher.name: Leibniz Institute of Plant Genetics and Crop Plant Research (IPK), Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description:
Introgression predictions for wheat collections from Schulthess et al. (2022, https://doi.org/10.1038/s41588-022-01189-7) using GBS and WGS data. Introgressions were predicted based on the percentage bases covered in 1-Mb windows along the Chinese Spring version 2.1 genome assembly. Introgressions are labeled with -1 or 1, while unchanged regions are labeled with 0. The label -1 indicates an unexpected low percentage of bases covered, while the label 1 indicates an unexpected high percentage of bases covered.

For more information, we refer to our paper 'Finding needles in a haystack: Identification of inter-specific introgressions in wheat genebank collections using low-coverage sequencing data' (https://doi.org/10.0.13.61/fpls.2023.1166854).

We also provide the R scripts that was used to label the genomic windows based on the coverage data.
keywords: wheat, introgression, genebank

name: Triticum vulgare
Genome-wide prediction of thousand kernel weight for 234 winter barley accessions from the ICARDA genebank using 1,910 IPK genebank accessions as training set

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: Genotyping-by-sequencing (GBS) was used to characterize 9,344 genebank samples from the German Federal ex situ winter barley collection (IPK genebank) plus 1,089 accessions from ICARDA genebank. GBS variants are according to MorexV3 reference genome. Among IPK genebank samples, 1,910 winter barley accessions have thousand grain weight (TGW) records and served as training set for genomic predictions of 234 ICARDA genebank accession of the winter group. Genomic predictions and their standard errors were computed using (1) Genomic best linear unbiased prediction (GBLUP), (2) Extended genomic best linear unbiased prediction (EGBLUP), and (3) Reproducing kernel Hilbert space regression (RKHS). For further details on input and expected output files as well as R codes, please read the “README.txt” files.
keywords: Barley, genebanks, genome-wide prediction, ICARDA, IPK, prediction ability

name: AWN phenotyping tool- v0.1

publisher.name: Leibniz Institute of Plant Genetics and Crop Plant Research (IPK), Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: Consideration of the properties of awns is important for the phenotypic description of grain crops. Awns have a number of important functions in grasses, including assimilation, mechanical protection and seed dispersal and burial. An important feature of the awn is the presence or absence of barbs, - tiny hook-like single-celled trichomes on the outer awn surface that can be visualized using microscopic imaging. The awn phenotyping tool performs the automated analysis (detection and quantification) of these small, semi-transparent structures in a high-throughput manner. The project folder contains both Linux and Windows compiled version tools to download and use for the end users.
keywords: Image analysis, Computer vision, Plant phenotyping, Barley awn

name: Genomic SNP profiles for 100 winter wheat lines

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: A 70,000 single-nucleotide-polymorphism (SNP) array, which derived from the original 90,000 Illumina Infinium Chip array (https://doi.org/10.1111/pbi.12183), was used to characterize 100 elite wheat lines. All SNPs with more than 25% missing values were eliminated from the dataset. In addition, missing genotypic information was imputed using the random forest method as implemented in the missForest R package V1 (https://doi.org/10.1093/bioinformatics/btr597). In total, the genomic SNP profile dataset comprises 16,393 markers. For each marker, the two alleles at homozygous state are coded as 0 and 2, respectively, while 1 denotes heterozygous genotypes.
keywords: Winter wheat, 100 lines, single-nucleotide-polymorphismus (SNP) array

name: Pseudonymized phenotypic and genotypic data from two stages of rye (Secale cereale) hybrid breeding program as implemented during 2018 to 2021 at KWS SAAT SE & Co. KGaA

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: Rye hybrids are derived from a cross between a CMS (cytoplasmic male sterile) intra-pool hybrid as seed parent and a restorer synthetic as pollinator parent. The breeding program for rye hybrids involves crossing and development of parental inbred lines and a multistage general combining ability (GCA) testing using testers from the opposite heterotic pool. A subset of genotypes of the phenotypic records from stages 1 and 2 of GCA tests implemented as part of a multistage hybrid rye program at KWS SAAT SE & Co. KGaA are presented here at two different resolutions. The dataset 1 contains design effect corrected BLUE (best linear unbiased estimates) values for plant height and grain dry matter yield for each physical trial. The BLUE values have not been adjusted for the trial effect. Tested genotypes belong to three consecutive cycles of GCA testing in the years 2018-2019, 2019-2020 and 2020-2021. In each cycle, selected genotypes from GCA1 were passed on to the next year of testing (GCA2). The dataset 2 contains raw phenotypic records from a single year of testing i.e., including design effects for the same traits. The observations were made on hybrids in both datasets. There is no overlap between the two datasets for the hybrids evaluated and hence both are presented separately along with their respective genotype data. Each dataset folder contains a phenotypic data and genotypic data subdirectory. The phenotypic data for the respective datasets is formatted with ISA-TAB (https://isa-specs.readthedocs.io/en/latest/isamodel.html) while the genotypic data follows a generic formatting wherein a descriptor file has been included describing the contents of genotypic data.
keywords: Phenotypic data, Genotypic data, Rye, Secale cereale , Dry matter yield, Plant height, GCA, Hybrid Breeding, Inbred Line

name: DNA-Sequence amendment to dataset 'Enhancing a Sphaerobacter thermophilus ω-transaminase for kinetic resolution of β- and γ-amino acids'.

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description:
This data set contains the StoTA.fasta. The sequence is a supplemental to an already existing data set with the title 
'Enhancing a Sphaerobacter thermophilus ω-transaminase for kinetic resolution of β- and γ-amino acids' (DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.5447/ipk/2023/12). 

StoTA.fasta contains the sequence of the tast gene in fasta format. This gene was derived from Sphaerobacter thermophilus, it codes for an omega transaminase. 
The sequence is based on the one from the rcsb entry 6K8H and it was codon optimized for E. coli. This sequence was used to create the data, which can be found 
under the DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.5447/ipk/2023/12
keywords: ω-transaminase, Sphaerobacter thermophilus, fasta

name: Phenotyping dataset of the PREDICT canola population

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: In frame of the PREDICT project, a diverse spring-type canola (Brassica napus) population with 477 individuals (475 pollinators and two male sterile lines), 120 selected hybrids, and two commercial checks were analysed by automated non-invasive phenotyping. The material originated from a commercial NPZi breeding programme. Plants were cultivated and phenotyped in the IPK phenotyping facility for large plants (Junker et al. 2015) under controlled spring-like environmental conditions in an incomplete randomized block design with three replicates as described in Knoch et al. (2020 & 2021). Each replicate consisted of a pot with nine plants. A total of five phenotyping experiments were performed. Plants were imaged daily using visible light (VIS), static fluorescence (FLUO) and near-infrared (NIR) camera systems for the period between 6 and 27 days after sowing (DAS), acquiring top and sideview images. At 14 DAS, shoot material of four plants was sampled for molecular/biochemical analyses. Shoot fresh and dry weights of the remaining five plants were determined at 28 DAS. The phenotyping dataset has been uploaded in ISA-Tab format and meets the MIAPPE standard (Papoutsoglou et al., 2020).
keywords: biomass and growth, Brassica napus, high-throughput phenotyping (HTP), image analysis, Integrated Analysis Platform (IAP), vegetative plant development

name: Leveraging the diversity in grain protein and lysine content across the winter wheat genebank collection hosted at the Leibniz Institute of Plant Genetics and Crop Plant Research

publisher.name: e!DAL - Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository (PGP), IPK Gatersleben, Seeland OT Gatersleben, Corrensstraße 3, 06466, Germany

description: Between 1970 and 1986, the winter wheat collection hosted at the Leibniz Institute of Plant Genetics and Crop Plant Research was tested for grain protein as well as lysine content. The evaluation was partially replicated. The resulting dataset originated from 5,953 field plots for a total of 4,971 accessions. The present publication does not only include the dataset which is published here following the ISA-Tab format; moreover, the R software code implemented for the analysis of the data is disclosed together with the most important output files. The software code includes: (i) the integrated analysis of the dataset yielding adjusted entry means (BLUEs) across years, (ii) the comparison of four genomic prediction models based on their prediction ability, and (iii) genomic predictions of the traits protein content, lysine content, thousand grain weight, and adjusted lysine content for 7,745 genotyped accession samples of winter wheat engaging the most accurate model.
keywords: genomic prediction, grain quality, lysine content, protein content, wheat
